description:
Dickeya aquatica is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Dickeya, which is a member of the family Pectobacteriaceae. This species is classified as a Gram-negative, rod-shaped, facultatively anaerobic bacterium.

Dickeya aquatica is known to be an aquatic species, meaning it is commonly found in aquatic environments, such as freshwater systems like rivers, lakes, and ponds. The bacterium is capable of causing soft rot diseases in a variety of plant species, particularly those growing in aquatic or semi-aquatic habitats.

The specific pathogenic mechanisms and host range of Dickeya aquatica are still under investigation, but it is believed to possess the ability to produce various enzymes and phytotoxins that contribute to its plant-pathogenic nature. Further research is needed to fully understand the ecology, epidemiology, and potential impact of this aquatic Dickeya species on aquatic and wetland plant communities.
